awd_titl_txt: Moist Tropical Waves and the Basic State
awd_abstract_narration:
Weather in the tropics is known to importantly affect weather at higher latitudes, including over the continental United States. This project will improve understanding of two prominent types of tropical weather patterns, known as convectively coupled Kelvin waves and the Madden Julian Oscillation. Addressing this issue will help to answer several longstanding scientific questions, such as why does rainfall associated with the Madden Julian Oscillation tend to be confined almost exclusively to the Indo-Pacific sector of the tropics? This new knowledge will help to bolster efforts by the broader scientific community aimed at improving models for predicting weather and climate, as a tangible benefit to society. The project will also provide training to a postdoctoral scientist and mentoring of undergraduate students from underrepresented groups, thereby helping to broaden the demographics and skills of the future workforce.     

Specifically, the project will use numerical models in conjunction with observations to investigate how and why these disturbances are both seen to be strongly modulated by the local basic state (or environment) in which they are embedded. The project will also investigate the structures and mechanisms of an apparently distinct class of convectively coupled Kelvin waves, whose existence and propagation depend crucially on forcing of the tropics by midlatitude weather patterns.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main outcome of the project was a set of five peer-reviewed publications in scientific journals. Taken together, these publications document a critical role of the climatological (or "background") zonal winds in shaping the existence and behavioral characteristics of two important types of large-scale, eastward-moving tropical weather variability. The first is the Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO), whose observed regional confinement to the tropical Indo-Pacific was shown for the first time to be a consequence of the unique presence of widespread background westerlies at low-levels over the equator, together with off-equatorial background easterlies. The reason stems from the effects of this particular type of mean flow configuration on the nature of interactions between different types of large-scale wave circulations in the tropics, which ultimately help to drive the MJO's eastward propagation by causing drying of air columns to the west of the disturbance's convective envelope and moistening to the east. Meanwhile, evidence was given to suggest that the reason why the MJO tends to be strongest during northern hemisphere winter is due to the fact that subtropical westerlies at upper levels in the atmosphere tend to be strongest on average during this season. The reason is that a stronger jet enables upper-level circulation anomalies excited by the MJO to be more effective in driving precipitation anomalies. 

Moist Kelvin waves are the second type of eastward-moving tropical weather phenomena whose existence and behavioral characteristics were found to importantly depend on the structure of the background zonal flow. In thus case, however, the mechanism is primarily through mediation of tropical-extratropical interactions, in addition to Doppler shifting effects. Specifically, results from sophisticated model calculations, as well as careful processing of observations, showed how moist Kelvin waves tend to be resonantly excited by eastward-moving weather patterns in the midlatitudes under certain mean flow conditions, namely, when the speed of the upper-level background zonal winds in the subtropics is equal to the speed at which Kelvin waves propagate (modulo the Doppler-shifting effect of upper-level zonal winds at the equator). 
The above scientific outcomes are expected to have a broader impact in field of global weather and climate prediction, by isolating the mechanistic processes that must be accurately represented in order to simulate the MJO and moist Kelvin waves. Improving the simulation of these disturbances is of known practical importance, owing to their well-documented tendency to affect high-impact weather events, including tropical storms. Funds of the project supported the mentoring of several post-docs, thereby helping to advance the scientific expertise of the US workforce.
